programme.title: 2024 NCAA Women's Basketball Tournament
programme.desc: The No. 1 Gamecocks (36-0) face the No. 3 Wolfpack (31-6) in the NCAA Tournament's Final Four. Ashlyn Watkins came off the bench to post 14 rebounds and four blocks in South Carolina's Elite Eight win over Oregon State. NC State ousted No. 1 Texas.

programme.title: 2024 NCAA Women's Basketball Tournament
programme.desc: The No. 1 Hawkeyes draw the No. 3 Huskies in the NCAA Tournament's Final Four. Clark scored 41 points for the second straight time in the regional finals, leading Iowa to a win over LSU in its Elite Eight title-game rematch. UConn upended No. 1 USC.

programme.title: SportsCenter With Scott Van Pelt
programme.desc: SVP's up at midnight and bringing his unique perspective on games people play to "SportsCenter" viewers. The hourlong, late-night show is driven by the host's self-deprecating wit and passion for sports, with featured elements, including Van Pelt's nightly "1 Big Thing" commentary and a weekly look back at the moments that drove bettors wild in "Bad Beats." The show also delivers what "SportsCenter" fans are used to -- news and highlights, guests and interviews -- but in a different, fast-paced and insightful way.

programme.title: SportsCenter With Scott Van Pelt
programme.desc: SVP's up at midnight and bringing his unique perspective on games people play to "SportsCenter" viewers. The hourlong, late-night show is driven by the host's self-deprecating wit and passion for sports, with featured elements, including Van Pelt's nightly "1 Big Thing" commentary and a weekly look back at the moments that drove bettors wild in "Bad Beats." The show also delivers what "SportsCenter" fans are used to -- news and highlights, guests and interviews -- but in a different, fast-paced and insightful way.

programme.title: SportsCenter
programme.desc: The latest news, highlights and inside information from every corner of the sports world is presented each day on "SportsCenter," ESPN's first-ever program when the network debuted in September of 1979. The flagship series airs an evening edition and a brand new midnight show each weekday before the stage is cleared for a live "SportsCenter" morning block that emphasizes fast-paced, highlights-driven reports and what's new on social media platforms.

programme.title: United Football League
programme.desc: The Showboats (1-0) welcome the Brahmas (1-0) to Tennessee in Week 2. Quarterback Chase Garbers threw a pair of TD passes and scored another himself in San Antonio's 27-12 season-opening triumph over D.C. Memphis took down Houston 18-12 in Week 1.

programme.title: College GameDay
programme.desc: "College GameDay" gets fans ready for all the day's action in men's college basketball with exclusive interviews, analysis, behind-the-scenes features and predictions. The primary host is Rece Davis, joined by analysts Jay Bilas, Seth Greenberg and LaPhonso Ellis. The show typically originates from the site of one of the day's biggest games.

programme.title: Formula 1 Racing
programme.desc: The Japanese Grand Prix revs up at Suzuka Circuit. In Australia, Carlos Sainz capitalized on Max Verstappen's first retirement in two years to take his third race win and bring Ferrari within four points of Red Bull in the Constructors' standings.

programme.title: United Football League
programme.desc: The Stallions run into the Panthers in a battle of unbeaten clubs in Week 2 from Detroit. Defending USFL champion Birmingham took down XFL victor Arlington as the title-holders of the two merged leagues met to begin the UFL's inaugural campaign.

programme.title: 2024 NCAA Women's Basketball Tournament
programme.desc: Basketball legends and longtime friends Sue Bird and Diana Taurasi put their own spin on the championship game.

programme.title: NCAA Women's Basketball Championship Studio
programme.desc: Hosts and analysts discuss the NCAA women's basketball tournament.

programme.title: Baseball Tonight: Sunday Night Countdown
programme.desc: Leading into each of ESPN's Sunday Night Baseball telecasts is this special edition of "Baseball Tonight." Host Karl Ravech teams with analysts and reporters to present fans a detailed preview of the network's exclusive, national game of the week. Highlights of the day's other games, interviews with players and managers, and key storylines from around the league also fill the hourlong show. Mark Teixeira, Eduardo Pérez, Tim Kurkjian and Buster Olney are among the analysts.

programme.title: MLB Baseball
programme.desc: The Rangers and the Astros continue a four-game set, their first since the 2023 American League Championship Series. Houston sends out right-hander Ronel Blanco, who turned in the first no-hitter of the year in a 10-0 win over Toronto on April 1.

programme.title: NHL Hockey
programme.desc: The Avalanche look to assert their dominance over the Central-leading Stars in this clash of Stanley Cup contenders. Colorado has taken all three meetings with Dallas this season by a combined 16-8 line. Mikko Rantanen (COL) scored in all three wins.

programme.title: Get Up
programme.desc: ESPN's morning show features host Mike Greenberg with a rotating and diverse group of analysts opining about and analyzing the latest news from the world of sports. The two-hour, personality-driven show originates from Manhattan's South Street Seaport, a locale that attracts high-profile guests. Greenberg, aka "Greeny," is formerly one-half of ESPN Radio's longtime "Mike & Mike" morning show.

programme.title: First Take
programme.desc: Stephen A. Smith joins host Molly Qerim on this weekday morning sports debate show. Smith provides his expert takes on the day's trending sports topics and under-the-radar news. They're regularly joined by veteran analysts and the top guests in sports and entertainment.

programme.title: The Pat McAfee Show
programme.desc: Former NFL punter Pat McAfee brings his humor and candor to the microphone to highlight the day's top stories.

programme.title: SportsCenter
programme.desc: The latest news, highlights and inside information from every corner of the sports world is presented each day on "SportsCenter," ESPN's first-ever program when the network debuted in September of 1979. The flagship series airs an evening edition and a brand new midnight show each weekday before the stage is cleared for a live "SportsCenter" morning block that emphasizes fast-paced, highlights-driven reports and what's new on social media platforms.

programme.title: NBA Today
programme.desc: In-depth, comprehensive daily coverage of all aspects of the NBA from expert analysts.

programme.title: NFL Live
programme.desc: Host Laura Rutledge takes the helm of this weekday show featuring the likes of Marcus Spears, Dan Orlovsky, Mina Kimes, and Adam Schefter. The "NFL Live" crew entertains fans while offering all the latest news and analysis from across the NFL.

programme.title: Around the Horn
programme.desc: Hosted by Tony Reali in the ESPN studio and joined via satellite by four panelists from across the country, the team debates popular sports stories. Reali acts as moderator, giving points for well-made arguments and deducting points for those who inspire him to hit the "mute" button. At the end of the show, whomever Reali deems the winner has 30 seconds without interruption to voice their final opinions on any topic they want.

programme.title: Pardon the Interruption
programme.desc: The debate is the story in this fast-paced, half-hour series hosted by former Washington Post sportswriters Tony Kornheiser and Michael Wilbon. The pair engage in high-energy discussions, conduct interviews and often argue over topics not even related to sports. Other sports reporters appear as guests and offer opinions on the top stories of the day.

programme.desc: The Penguins continue pursuit of a postseason berth as they host the playoff-positioned Lightning. Pittsburgh sits outside both the second wild-card spot and third place in the Metropolitan. Tampa Bay halted a five-game series slide on Dec. 6, 2023.

programme.desc: When Skip Bertman arrives in Baton Rouge, La., in the summer of 1983 as LSU's new head baseball coach, the program is mired in mediocrity; from those beginnings, he turns the Tigers into a powerhouse, winning five national titles in a 10-year span.
